subject: Re: [junit] Re: class isolation and class order for testing
msgSnippet: ... Read Michael Feathers book /Working Effectively with Legacy Code/. ... I d suggest classes which are likely to be worked on soon . Those are, after all,
messageBody:
On Tuesday 15 January 2008 09:47, csabcsi.szucs wrote:

> I meant the following:
> I cannot do a TDD this time, because I have already an existing
> project with about 100 production classes (and some time to learn and
> exercise JUnit tests).

Read Michael Feathers' book /Working Effectively with Legacy Code/.

> So which class shall I start with to write JUnit tests for? Perhaps
> it is worth starting with a class that does not have any collaborators
> or only ones that are already tested in a previous "test phase".

I'd suggest classes which are likely to be worked on "soon". Those are,
after all, the ones which you might otherwise break, and for which
unit tests will add most value.

It's tempting to start with "easy" ones, but you run the risk of writing
tests for things that won't change and won't break, and you'd gain an
unrealistic view of how easy it is(n't) to add tests post-hoc.

--
"until you're/living with the unfamiliar" - October Project, /Take Me As I Am/
